description:
Dr. Kenzo Tenma is a renowned Japanese brain surgeon working at a leading hospital in Germany. One night, Dr. Tenma risks his reputation and career to save the life of a critically wounded young boy over that of the town mayor who had been planning to support the hospital financially. A string of mysterious murders begin to occur soon after the operation, and Dr. Tenma emerges as the primary suspect despite no incriminating evidence.

A doctor is taught to believe that all life is equal; however, when another series of murders occur in the surgeon's vicinity, Dr. Tenma's beliefs are shaken as his actions that night are shown to have much broader consequences than he could have imagined. Leaving behind his life as a surgeon he embarks on a journey across the country to unravel the mystery of the boy he saved.

tags.name: Crime
tags.description: Centers around unlawful activities punishable by the state or other authority.

tags.name: Seinen
tags.description: Target demographic is adult males.

tags.name: Detective
tags.description: Features a character who investigates and solves crimes.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Fugitive
tags.description: Prominently features a character evading capture by an individual or organization.

tags.name: Revenge
tags.description: Prominently features a character who aims to exact punishment in a resentful or vindictive manner.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Twins
tags.description: Prominently features two or more siblings that were born at one birth.

tags.name: Memory Manipulation
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) who has had their memories altered.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Noir
tags.description: Stylized as a cynical crime drama with low-key visuals.

tags.name: Conspiracy
tags.description: Contains one or more factions controlling or attempting to control the world from the shadows.

tags.name: Adoption
tags.description: Features a character who has been adopted by someone who is neither of their biological parents.

tags.name: Foreign
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a country outside the country of origin.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: Police
tags.description: Centers around the life and activities of law enforcement officers.

tags.name: Politics
tags.description: Centers around politics, politicians, or government activities.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Amnesia
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) with memory loss.

tags.name: Medicine
tags.description: Centered around the activities of people working in the field of medicine.

tags.name: Dissociative Identities
tags.description: A case where one or more people share the same body.

tags.name: Travel
tags.description: Centers around character(s) moving between places a significant distance apart.

tags.name: Orphan
tags.description: Prominently features a character that is an orphan.

tags.name: Historical
tags.description: Partly or completely set during a real period of world history.

tags.name: Time Skip
tags.description: Features a gap in time used to advance the story.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Suicide
tags.description: The act or an instance of taking or attempting to take one's own life voluntarily and intentionally.

tags.name: Primarily Male Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of male characters.

tags.name: Torture
tags.description: The act of deliberately inflicting severe pain or suffering upon another individual or oneself as a punishment or with a specific purpose.

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: Crossdressing
tags.description: Prominently features a character dressing up as the opposite sex.

tags.name: Gore
tags.description: Prominently features graphic bloodshed and violence.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

tags.name: Rescue
tags.description: Centers around operations that carry out urgent treatment of injuries, remove people from danger, or save lives. This includes series that are about search-and-rescue teams, trauma surgeons, firefighters, and more.

tags.name: Rape
tags.description: Features non-consensual sexual penetration.

tags.name: Bullying
tags.description: Prominently features the use of force for intimidation, often in a school setting.

node.description: __Hometown:__ Riverside, California Twitter | Instagram Between voice acting, script-adapting, and directing, Patrick Seitz has had the pleasure of working on hundreds of different video games and anime series over the past 20 years. His voice credits include Endeavor MHA, Franky One Piece, Dio JoJo’s Bizarre Adventure, plus a variety of video game voices like Arthas Menethil and Garrosh Hellscream from World of Warcraft. Seitz’s script-adapting credits include the English dubs of the animated feature films Summer Wars and Wolf Children, as well as series such as Aggretsuko, and he has directed a bevy of Japanese RPGs. _Source: Crunchyroll Expo 2020_

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/urasawa_naoki) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCkIFOAoFm47XOAlJwTa6Ieg) | [Spotify](https://open.spotify.com/artist/4kmbC7n35u81LaR7VKyaaX)

Naoki Urasawa's career as a manga artist spans more than twenty years and has firmly established him as one of the true manga masters of Japan. Born in Tokyo in 1960, Urasawa debuted with BETA! in 1983 and hasn't stopped his impressive output since. Well-versed in a variety of genres, Urasawa's oeuvre encompasses a multitude of different subjects, such as a romantic comedy ([Yawara! A Fashionable Judo Girl](https://anilist.co/manga/30853/Yawara/)), a suspenseful human drama about a former mercenary ([Pineapple ARMY](https://anilist.co/manga/30859/Pineapple-Army/); story by [Kazuya Kudo](https://anilist.co/staff/97206/Kazuya-Kudo)), a captivating psychological suspense story ([Monster](https://anilist.co/manga/30001/Monster/)), a sci-fi adventure manga ([20th Century Boys](https://anilist.co/manga/30003/20th-Century-Boys/)), and a modern reinterpretation of the work of the God of Manga, [Osamu Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/96938/Osamu-Tezuka) ([Pluto: Urasawa x Tezuka](https://anilist.co/manga/30745/Pluto/); co-authored with [Takashi Nagasaki](https://anilist.co/staff/112205/Takashi-Nagasaki), supervised by [Makoto Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/104143/Makoto-Tezuka), and with the cooperation of [Tezuka Productions](https://anilist.co/studio/200/Tezuka-Productions)). Many of his books have spawned popular animated and live-action TV programs and films, and 2008 saw the theatrical release of the first of three live-action Japanese films based on 20th Century Boys.  

No stranger to accolades and awards, Urasawa is a three-time recipient of the prestigious Shogakukan Manga Award, a two-time recipient of the Osamu Tezuka Cultural Prize, and has received the Kodansha Manga Award. Similarly, Monster has been nominated twice for the Eisner Award in America. Urasawa has also become involved in the world of academia, and in 2008 accepted a guest teaching post at Nagoya Zokei University, where he teaches courses in, of course, manga.

__Birthplace:__ Saitama, Japan

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E8%93%9C%E5%B3%B6%E9%82%A6%E6%98%8E) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kuniaki_Haishima)

Kuniaki Haishima is a Japanese musician and composer. He is known for his music in several anime and tokusatsu shows, as well as video games, films and dorama. His compositions for the Fuji TV series Tales of the Unusual are his most famous work, though he also composed the soundtrack for Metroid: Other M, for which he is known abroad. His most notable composition works in the anime industry include titles such as [Monster](https://anilist.co/anime/19/), [Master Keaton](https://anilist.co/anime/1483/) and [Macross Zero](https://anilist.co/anime/194/).

(Source: Wikipedia)

__Birthplace:__ Saitama, Japan

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E8%93%9C%E5%B3%B6%E9%82%A6%E6%98%8E) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kuniaki_Haishima)

A producer working for VAP.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/池田祐二) | [Studio Wyeth](https://www.studio-wyeth.jp/)

A prominent art director, as well as the founder and representative director of Studio Wyeth.

_Note: Not to be confused with animator [Yuuji Ikeda](https://anilist.co/staff/144426/)._
Originating from [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/). He is a member of the Writers Guild of Japan.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/136171134)

A long-serving anime producer, as well as a founder of [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/), [Mappa](https://anilist.co/studio/569/) and [Studio M2](https://anilist.co/studio/6137/). He currently serves as the Chairman of the Board at [Mappa](https://anilist.co/studio/569/).

Maruyama graduated from Hosei University in 1963, and soon after, he found work at [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/) in 1965. It was here that he met many of Madhouse's future staff members. In October 1972, he left Mushi Production together with [Rintarou](https://anilist.co/staff/102305/), [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393/) and [Yoshiaki Kawajiri](https://anilist.co/staff/100812/) and founded Madhouse. From that time onward, Maruyama focused mainly on producing and planning Madhouse's upcoming projects. He also served as the studio's president through the '80s and '90s.

Thanks in large part to his frequent attendance at anime conventions, he has become well-known in America among Madhouse's fanbase. Not simply wanting to emulate past successes, Maruyama frequently says at these events that his goal as a producer is to seek out new challenges that will allow the production staff to keep experimenting. This attitude in part has been the reason why he has encouraged the studio to take on projects that may not seem like sure-fire commercial hits. In addition, Maruyama has long been a supporter of bringing new talents into the animation business, and continues to encourage young people to work in anime.

In 2011, he left Madhouse and founded Mappa. Later in 2016, he left Mappa and founded Studio M2.

(Source: Wikipedia)

David Sylvian (born David Alan Batt) is an English singer-songwriter and musician who came to prominence in the late 1970s as frontman of the band Japan. He has collaborated widely with artists such as Ryuichi Sakamoto, Robert Fripp, Holger Czukay, and Fennesz. He is known for his androgynous appearance and unique voice, which as been cited by many visual kei bands, such as Luna Sea, X Japan, and L'Arc-en-Ciel, as a creative influence. 

Sylvian was commissioned to write "For the Love of Life", the ending theme for the anime adaptation of Naoki Urasawa's "Monster", on which he collaborated with Haishima Kuniaki. In the cover notes to the official soundtrack he said, "I was attracted to the Monster material by the moral dilemma faced by its central character. The calm surface of the music giving way to darker undercurrents, signifying the conscience of the lead protagonist and the themes of morality, fate, resignation, and free will."

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/87896126)

While studying at Nihon University, Katabuchi participated in the writing team of [Sherlock Hound](https://anilist.co/anime/1972/), which's production also involved [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/). After graduating, he joined [Telecom Animation Film](https://anilist.co/studio/94/).

In 1999, Katabuchi joined [Studio 4°C](https://anilist.co/studio/13/), where he directed [Princess Arete](https://anilist.co/anime/1028/). The movie was released in 2001 and won Excellent Works of the Year in the Domestic Feature Film Category at Tokyo International Anime Fair in 2002. He joined [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/) and worked for various animations including [Black Lagoon](https://anilist.co/anime/889/). In 2016, Katabuchi directed [In This Corner of the World](https://anilist.co/anime/15227/) which was released on November 12, 2016 in Japan, and planned to be released in fifteen countries including UK, France, Germany, Mexico and US.

Married to fellow director [Chie Uratani](https://anilist.co/staff/121177/).

Originating from Kaname Production, currently affiliated with [Kinema Citrus](https://anilist.co/studio/290/).

Known for directing shows such as [Monster](https://anilist.co/anime/19/), [Made in Abyss](https://anilist.co/anime/97986/) and [Hanada Shounen-shi](https://anilist.co/anime/2004/).

**Birthplace:** Fukuoka, Japan

Yukihiro Miyamoto, occasionally nicknamed Otokomatsuri, is a Japanese animator and director. He started at animation studio Vega Entertainment, and later joined Shaft. He is best known for directing Puella Magi Madoka Magica and its subsequent film trilogy alongside Akiyuki Shinbo, the latter trilogy which subsequently garnered ¥2 billion, making it a box-office success.

Miyamoto described himself as being a "heretic" at Shaft-- someone who, in a company of many differing directors, is only good at doing "plain work", and isn't particularly original or creative. Shinbo described Miyamoto in a similar way, but said that he was more like a professional craftsman who leaves their mark in places that cannot be seen.

**Birthplace:** Fukuoka, Japan
